text: Five Spots To Try This Weekend Where to drink and dine on your days off share It's officially Friday: time to clock off and get those weekend vibes started. No plans yet? No problem! Eater's here with a handy round up of recently opened restaurants, new-to-you bars, seasonal menu changes, chef debuts and more. Whether you’re hankering for an after work happy hour - or the lowdown on this weekend’s culinary events, beer festivals or Sunday Brunch bites - our regular weekly feature will be sure to help you make the most of that well-earned downtime. FEBRUARY 24, 2017 Oscar Viewing Party: Pacifica Del Mar Watch the Oscars at Pacifica’s Ocean Bar on Sunday, February 26. Start with red carpet arrivals at 4 p.m., and stay for the awards. Enjoy happy hour all night, with half off items including tacos, oyster shooters and flatbreads, or sip on a martini from the International Vodka Bar. Diners can also cast their vote on Pacifica’s ballots for a chance to win gift cards to the restaurant. 1555 Camino Del Mar (858) 792-0476 Courtesy Photo Academy Awards Viewing Party: True North Tavern Tickets start at just $25 and are are available online for the Academy Awards viewing party at True North Tavern in North Park. Movie lovers can walk the Red Carpet and enjoy a complimentary glass of champagne upon arrival at 4:30 p.m. this Sunday before heading inside where tray-passed hors d'oeuvres and specialty food stations, plus drinks, beer and cocktails from two full-service bars and 30 taps await. 3815 30th Street (619) 291-3815 Photo: Yelp Oscars Benefit Night: Bella Vista Social Club & Caffé Sleek counter-serve spot Bella Vista Social Club and Caffé , is hosting a benefit Oscars night this Sunday, February 26 to raise funds for youth with economic needs to attend performing arts programs in San Diego. A pre-Oscars Red Carpet show from 4 to 5:30 p.m. will feature a jazz ensemble, vocalist, and dance performers. Streaming of the Oscars will follow with a silent auction and additional entertainment. Tickets cost between $75 and $125 and can be purchased online . 2880 Torrey Pines Scenic Dr (858) 534-9624 Photo: Yelp Oscar Viewing Party: Cinema Under The Stars Enjoy small plates from sponsor restaurants Patio on Goldfinch and Lefty’s Chicago Pizzeria , plus house beverages including Stella Artois, red, white and sparkling wines, at Cinema Under The Stars Oscar viewing party this Sunday. Kicking off at 4:30 p.m., get snapped on the red carpet before taking your seats inside the intimate theater and catching all the glitz and glamor live and direct from Hollywood. Tickets cost $60 and can be purchased by calling (619) 295-4221. 4040 Goldfinch St. Photo: Yelp Oscar Awards Viewing Party: San Diego Film Festival Walk the red carpet and watch the Academy Awards in style in this black tie optional San Diego Film Festival fundraiser. Enjoy signature dishes from premier San Diego chefs (The Marine Room, Crudo, Galaxy Taco) while sipping elegantly crafted Snake Oil Co. Signature cocktails. Desserts and champagne toasts will cap off the party, which is being held from 4:30 p.m. to 10 p.m. Limited tickets are available for the event, which will be held at a private estate in La Jolla, and cost $125 per person - includes open bar, food and valet parking. (619) 818-2221 FEBRUARY 17, 2017 Yelp La Mesa residents can now satisfy their noodle cravings at this newly opened spot in East County. Serving lunch and dinner, here you’ll find a range of specialty bowls on the menu including the pork broth/tonkatsu Blvd Bowl and chai-su pork belly Helix Bowl, plus bao bun tacos, crispy chicken wings, an all-beef lumpia plate, and tender chunks of karaage served with ponzu. There’s also a great happy hour from 3 p.m. to 5 p.m. where you can get two appetizers for the price of one. For drinks you’ll find a draft beers (Stone and Pizza Port, plus Sapporo Premium) in addition to a selection of sake, including Bushido Sake on nitro. 8325 La Mesa Blvd. (619) 467-7999 Photo: Facebook Chamorro Food: Guahan Grill For a taste of Guam head to this new spot in the Midway District which serves up authentic Chamorro dishes like Kelaguen (chopped barbecued chicken mixed with lemon, green onions and hot pepper) and Kadun Pika: chicken simmered with onions, garlic, hot pepper, coconut milk, vinegar and soy sauce. There’s a Spam and Portuguese sausage plate or ‘Guam Bomb’ of homemade fries topped with chicken, onions, Swiss cheese, barbecue sauce and spicy mayo if you’re super hungry. Lunch specials, like a poke bowl or Chamorro fried rice, ring in for just under $10 Tuesday through Friday until 3 p.m. Guahan Grill is open 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily and closed on Mondays. 3373 Rosecrans St. (619) 693-5766 Photo: Yelp New Brews for 2017: Alpine Beer Company Award-winning craft brewery Alpine Beer Company is adding several new products to its lineup this year including their first-ever canned offerings as well as a new single IPA called "Windows Up". In addition, Alpine will be debuting several limited-edition beers exclusively in their tasting room in the coming months. Newest IPA addition, Windows Up , has got big hop aromatics and a ‘dank’ bold flavor profile with very little bitterness; while About Truck Trail Ale , which is named for the Anderson Truck Trail, features a balanced blend of Cascade and Centennial hops with dominant notes of fresh pine needles and zesty citrus rind. 2363 Alpine Blvd (619) 445-2337 Courtesy Photo Guy’s Grocery Games Dinner: Eclipse Chocolate In celebration of founder and chocolatier Will Gustwiller ’s recent win on the Food Network Show Guy’s Grocery Games Eclipse Chocolate will host a special dinner and viewing party on Saturday, February 18. Featuring a three-course tasting menu that mimics Will Gustwiller’s winning dishes, diners can catch the special “Guy’s Chocolate Games” episode and meet the man himself, in addition to building their own large chocolate bar using a selection of 30 plus ingredients like butter toffee, pink peppercorn, and vanilla sea salt. With seatings available at 5 p.m. and 8 p.m. tickets cost $47 per person and are available to purchase online . New Menu Items: Duck Dive Take a culinary trip down the California and Baja coast with new food items on the menu at this casual Mission Beach hangout . Newly added gastropub-inspired fare includes a steamed Baja Bowl of assorted shellfish, green chorizo broth, roasted corn and poblanos, which comes with grilled sourdough bread; and the Puerto Nuevo Plato comprising a broiled lobster tail, roasted poblano and corn cilantro rice, black beans, queso fresco and jalapeño cream. From the Dive Street Cart , you’ll find a seafood ceviche tostada, poke taco and a citrus filet taco. Enjoy with Duck Dive’s rotating lineup of local and micro brews, plus craft cocktails. 4650 Mission Blvd (858) 273-3825 Photo FEBRUARY 10, 2017 New Szechuan in Sorrento Valley: Mr. Holy Gao Previously called Han's Kitchen this cash-only spot re-opened as Mr. Holy Gao in Sorrento Valley at the end of last year. Serving up authentic Chinese with a Szechuan focus, here you’ll find typical dishes, like kung pao chicken and dry-friend green beans, casseroles and hot pots, plus a weekend northern dim sum menu. Early reviews are favorable, highlighting dishes such as cumin lamb and smoked pork with garlic chives, spicy tea smoked duck, Beijing style lamb hot pot, and pork belly braised with preserved napa in brown sauce. 10066 Pacific Heights Blvd(858) 587-3916 Photo: Yelp Three-course Dinner & Cabaret : THE US GRANT In conjunction with the iconic Lamb’s Players Theater THE US GRANT will be hosting a special three-course dinner and a cabaret show this weekend on both Saturday and Sunday nights, with a finale on Valentine’s Day evening. Meal highlights include charcuterie, lobster ravioli with champagne buerre blanc, and a raspberry chocolate cake with a white chocolate mocha sauce to finish. During dinner guests can enjoy romantic melodies performed live by a dozen of San Diego’s best singers. Tickets are priced at $94 per person for a table. 326 Broadway (619) 232-3121 Courtesy Photo Chocolate Making Classes: Sweet Petite Confections On Saturday, February 11 chocolatier Michelle Lomelin will lead a “Make Sweets with Your Sweetheart” chocolate class at her artisan chocolate shop in Clairemont from 12:30 to 3 p.m. Participants will get to fill chocolate molds with champagne caramel and serrano chili ganache among other flavors, and will use ingredients like raspberries, strawberries and candied bacon to personalize their own chocolate bark. Sweet-toothed students will leave with approximately 1.5 lbs of chocolate! Each class is priced at $40 per person, are all ages and reservations must be placed in advance online or by phone. 3582 Mt Acadia Blvd (858) 688-0210 Photo: Yelp Early Bird Valentine’s Day Menu: Pacific Standard Coastal Kitchen Enjoy chef Giselle Wellman 's special Valentine’s Day menu a day early on Sunday, February 12 at Pacific Standard . A la Carte options include oysters with champagne gelée and strawberry granita, plus bone marrow or roasted asparagus as a first course. For mains there’s a 22 oz. ribeye steak or whole snapper. Desserts include hazelnut, dark chocolate & passion fruit, plus a delicate strawberry, white chocolate & rose water dish accompanied by complimentary personalized cookies decorated with yours and your date’s names. 2137 Pacific Hwy (619) 819-0090 Courtesy Photo Chocolate & Wine Tasting: L’Auberge Del Mar Savor luscious artisan chocolates with red wine pairings on The Sunset Terrace at L’Auberge Del Mar this Saturday, February 11. Priced at $25 per person the tasting session runs from 4 to 6 p.m. and will feature chocolates by local Chuao Chocolatier and San Diego’s Dallmann Fine Chocolates. Next, head over to Coastline for cocktails and special shellfish selections from the raw bar between 6 to 9 p.m. The West Coast oyster tasting will feature Kusshi, Kumamoto and Fanny Bay bivalves ($3 each), plus poached tiger shrimp, King crab mini martini, and white bass with satsuma aguachile, fennel and blood orange. 1540 Camino Del Mar (858) 259-1515 Courtesy Photo FEBRUARY 3, 2017 Argentine & Salvadoran Eats: Che Calavera Chef/owners Facundo Defraia (who hails from Buenos Aires) and Tony Padilla (who was born in San Salvador) cook from the heart and soul at this new neighborhood gem in Mission Beach. Here, their simple from scratch and health-conscious menu centers on empanadas, rustic sandwiches, and traditional Salvadoran dish - papusa – plus small bites like bacon wrapped dates, yucca fries, fresh grilled corn on the cob and roasted cauliflower. A trio of empanadas, which comes with a side of chimichurri, costs $10 or $3 a piece if you buy separately - fillings include ground beef, braised chicken breast, and cheese and leeks. A delectable ‘platanos & frijoles’ plate ($15) gets you two fried plantains, eggs, avocado, cilantro and fresno pepper jasmine rice, plus a generous serving of house made salsa verde. Che Calavera is open daily from 11 a.m. – 9 p.m. 3852 Mission Blvd (858) 230-6522 Photo: Yelp Melt In The Mouth Meats: Primitive Smoke BBQ Le Cordon Bleu alum Brandon Haynie and San Diego Culinary Institute grad Jermaine Spotwood (who worked together at The Grand Del Mar) joined forces to bring their version of authentic barbecue to Pacific Beach. At Primitive Smoked BBQ you’ll find succulent, hickory-smoked all natural meats - from brisket and pulled pork to spare ribs, hot links and more – available as a plate or sandwich, plus scratch-made classic comfort sides and sauces. Come hungry for the Caveman Sampler ($32.99) 1 1/4 pounds of their signature smoked meats, plus assorted extras. Opened just last week Primitivehas already been garnering rave reviews online, stop by Tuesday through Sunday from 11 a.m. until sold out. 1037 Garnet Ave (858) 230-7212 Photo: Facebook Build Your Own Piña Colada Bar: Kettner Exchange Brunch aficionados will be pleased to know that KEX is launching a new menu of brunch cocktails, plus an awesome sounding Jimmy “Buffet” build-your-own Piña Colada Bar on Saturday, February 4 . Guests can choose up to three rums, like Hamilton’s Demerara 86 or Mount Gay Black Barrel, to build their perfect blended or unblended ‘piña before adding two additional exotic flavors - think orgeat, mango, blood orange - and up to three garnishes like mint, an orchid flower or piña leaf. New cocktail selections include Stone Blossom blended with whiskey, apricot liqueur, pineapple, lemon, and demerara, plus East Street - crafted with gin, St. Germain, lemon, soda, champagne and cucumber it serves 2 - 4 people. 2001 Kettner Blvd (619) 255-2001 Courtesy Photo New & Improved Brunch Menu: The Embarcadero Shack Purveyors of fine porcine products Carnitas Snack Shack just rolled out a new brunch menu at its Embarcadero location . Every Saturday and Sunday from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. feast on applewood smoked bacon pancakes smothered in maple syrup ($6.50), a breakfast quesadilla stuffed with carnitas, scrambled eggs, and pico de gallo ($8), plus biscuits & gravy, complete with crispy chicken and a sunny side up egg ($8.50). Bar manager Mai Pham ’s range of breakfast-friendly beverages include mimosas (OJ, grapefruit, pineapple), a Bloody Mary, French 75, and an Irish coffee. While Carnitas’ North Park location doesn’t offer brunch yet you can still enjoy $6 mimosas there on weekends. 1004 N Harbor Drive (619) 696-7675 Photo: Lyudmila Zotova Cheers To New Cocktails: Rustic Root The Gaslamp’s first dedicated restaurant and rooftop bar, Rustic Root , recently launched a line up of new cocktails, sure to make the perfect accompaniment to its menu of classic American cuisine. Full of seasonal flavor, highlights of these thoughtfully designed libations include: Fig Tree: Belvedere, Orgeat, lemon juice, house-made fig jam. Rose Sangria: Chandon Ros é , brandy, strawberries, orange slices, lemon juice, herb-infused simple syrup. Blood and Moon: Azunia Blanco, ginger snap liqueur, lemon juice, pumpkin puree. And, Rye Not: Wild Turkey Rye, lemon juice, ginger, lavender syrup. Cheers! 535 Fifth Ave (619) 232-1747 Photo: Antonio Cabral JANUARY 27, 2017 Now Open to Locals: Seasons Restaurant Luxury resort Four Seasons Residence Club Aviara just opened its signature restaurant to the public. At Seasons locals and visitors alike can now enjoy seasonal breakfast, lunch, and dinner menus from chef de cuisine Conor Ball and his team using produce sourced in part from local farms. Dishes range from short rib tacos with kimchi and a mariner’s stew with fresh market catch, to the whimsical ‘terrarium’ dessert made with pineapple foam, coconut sorbet, and local flowers. There’s a weekend brunch too (11 a.m. to 2 p.m. Saturday and Sunday), plus a pretty spiffing ingredient-driven cocktail program. Enjoy multiple distinctive dining experiences, including indoor and outdoor seating, a family-style Chef’s Table and a signature one-of-a-kind Kitchen Counter experience, which offers “front-row” seats to watch chef Ball and his team in action. 7210 Blue Heron Place (800) 622-4269 Courtesy Photo New Pie Shop in IB: Pizzeria Luigi Beloved Golden Hill Pizzeria Luigi has been serving up its award-winning New York-style pies in Imperial Beach since opening its third outpost there in early December. You may already be familiar with this San Diego staple from a certain Food Network show, if not their popular pizzas come with a range of set toppings - from classics and local favorites, to veggie (there’s a vegan-friendly tofu ricotta), plus build your own options. Standouts include the Sports Bar , heaped with potato, bacon and sour cream, and the meatball and ricotta-laden Crime Scene . For around $7 you’ll get two slices and a soda. Open daily from 11 a.m. enjoy $2 beer specials during happy hour (2-5 p.m.) and $2 PBR cans all day long. 717 Seacoast (619) 271-3477 Photo: Facebook Weekend Brunch: Encontro North Park Popular casual counter service concept Encontro debuted a new brunch menu this month. Highlights include the cinnamon French toast made with brioche and topped with strawberries, blackberries, powdered sugar, blueberry syrup, it’s served a la mode with Hammond’s vanilla bean ice cream. Hit it hard last night? Try the Encontro Hangover Cure : chorizo, scrambled egg, crispy potatoes, jalapeño, black beans and melted cheddar should get you feeling tip-tip in no time. Beverages include bacon bloodies and bottomless mimosas, for a caffeine fix there’s a French press dark roast, and cold brew coffee on nitro. 3001 University Ave (619) 291-1220 Photo: Lyudmila Zotova Late Night Bites: Larry’s Deli Downtown denizens will be pleased to know that Larry’s Deli just launched a new late night menu. Dubbed Larry’s Late Night you’ll find favorites like the Philly cheese steak alongside a PB&J French toast, and spicy mac n cheese bricks, which is a literal brick of macaroni and cheese that is seriously delicious. The menu also includes Larry’s Famous Frito Pie (served straight up in a Fritos bag), grilled cheese "cheese cheese", plus Larry’s traditional Reuben. Fix those comfort food and midnight cravings when Larry’s Deli reopens from 11 p.m. until 2 a.m. 323 Seventh Ave (619) 795-7100 Photo: Lyudmila Zotova National Blueberry Pancake Day: Cafe 222 For the uninitiated, its National Blueberry Pancake Day on Saturday, January 28 and in honor of this light, fluffy and golden brown delicious treat Terryl Gavre ’s quaint and quirky breakfast spot Cafe 222 will be flipping a bounty of blueberry pancakes. Made with the freshest and bluest of berries, look for them on the menu throughout the day. Mark your calendars for more menu specials in the coming months as Cafe 222 celebrates its 25 th anniversary this year. 222 Island Ave (619) 236-9902 Courtesy Photo JANUARY 20, 2017 Farmers, Friends & Fishermen Dinner: The Red Door Round off San Diego Restaurant Week in style with The Red Door’ s farm-to-table dinner on Sunday, January 22 . Showcasing freshly harvested produce from Dickinson Farm , Wild Willow Farm , Save Good Food , and Red Door Family Garden , the five-course ‘vegetarian tribute’ will be complimented by talks from the farmers, winemakers and chefs who made it possible. With two seating times available (4:30 p.m. and 7:30 p.m.) tickets cost $75, include gratuity and can be purchased here until Saturday, January 21. An optional Domaine Artefact wine pairing costs $25 and can be purchased online or in person at the event. 741 W Washington St (619) 295-6000 Photo: Lyudmila Zotova New Brunch + Dinner Menus: Decoy Dockside Dining Executive chef David Warner ’srecent revamp of the dinner menu at lakeside dining destination Decoy showcases local produce from citrus and seafood to foraged wild mushrooms. Here, you’ll be spoiled for choice with starters like woodfired Spanish octopus, and fresh-from-the-oven corn bread served with jalapeño jelly. Entrée standouts include a lemon and herb stuffed whole branzino, and a 10 oz. bison NY steak with chimichurri. For dessert don’t miss the goat’s milk panna cotta. Decoy’s brand new brunch menu also recently debuted and is filled with breakfast favorites “with a twist” like lemon ricotta French toast and Dockside eggs Benedict with sautéed jumbo crab and grilled asparagus. 1025 La Bonita Drive (760) 744-0120 Courtesy Photo New Extended Hours: Herb & Eatery Little Italy marketplace Herb & Eatery just announced new extended hours. Now open daily from 8 a.m. until 8 p.m., here you can load up freshly baked pastries, breads and croissants from executive pastry chef Adrian Mendoza during breakfast, or grab to-go salads, sandwiches, select entrees and appetizers for lunch or dinner. After 4 p.m. ‘Chef’s Specials’ are a highlight of the menu and showcase dishes inspired by creations from the wood-fired oven next door at Herb & Wood. Gourmet meal options aside; the bright and breezy space is also stocked with epicurean finds, from artisan salt, honey and tea, to locally made sauces. 2210 Kettner Blvd (619) 794-2790 Photo: Becca Batista Weekend Brunch Debut: Beerfish Popular seafood spot Beerfish debuts a new ocean-friendly brunch menu on Saturday, January 21 . The ongoing service is set to run every Saturday and Sunday from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. when diners can tuck into half a dozen new dishes by chef RoseAna Peyron . Priced between $13 and $18, highlights include a breakfast burrito stuffed with Maine lobster, blue crab Benedict smothered in Tabasco hollandaise, and wild coho smoked salmon scramble with roasted red peppers and dill crème fraîche. Enjoy alongside mimosas, Bloodies or one of thirty craft beers on tap. Walk-ins are welcome but reservations can also be made by calling ahead. 2933 Adams Ave (619) 363-2337 Photo: Lyudmila Zotova Vietnamese Steam Buns: T.P. Banh Bao 3 Quite possibly the first dedicated bánh bao shop in town, this family-owned spot (which also boasts an outpost in Garden Grove) soft opened their San Diego location around Christmas. Located within an unassuming strip mall in Mira Mesa they specialize in authentic, fresh made Vietnamese steamed buns, of which there 16 different types to choose from - and which you can watch being made through the open kitchen. Fluffy, doughy buns are stuffed with tasty fillings like pork and quail egg, chicken barbecue, and sausage Protip: try a few deep-fried and drizzled with sriracha. There are sweet options too, including a custard and durian version. Eater hears that the service is fast and friendly, and prices are decent ranging from $1 a piece to $12 for a box of nine. 11271 Camino Ruiz (858) 860-5226 Photo: Yelp JANUARY 13, 2017 New Sunday Brunch: Ponsaty’s Beginning Sunday, January 15 you will be able to enjoy an elegant weekend brunch at Master French Chef Patrick Ponsaty ’s signature restaurant in Rancho Santa Fe. Crafted to appease all appetites, dish highlights include herb crusted prime ribeye with a horseradish sauce; seawater poached King Crab Legs with French cocktail sauce, and a show-stopping egg Benedict Florentine. Priced at $49 per adult and $25 for kids, diners can also add on bottomless mimosas or Bloody Marys for an extra $15. 6106 Paseo Delicias (858) 771-1871 Courtesy Photo Submarine Crab - Yelp Grand opened on New Year’s Day, this is the place to come in Kearny Mesa if you’re looking to load up on Cajun and Creole style seafood. A diverse menu encompasses everything from crawfish and Canadian/King crab to lobster, live oysters and Green Lipped mussels. Popular ‘combos’ comprise generous amounts of corn, potato and sausage, plus your choice of aforementioned shellfish. Refreshments include tea, soda, and Ocean Fog specialty drinks (Captain Andy's, Green Sea Monster, The Mermaid, The Seahorse) which come served in a carafe complete with a swirling dry ice ‘fog’. Check in on social media to receive a pound of shrimp/crawfish with any combo, plus a free soft drink. As one Yelp reviewer says, “If you're looking for a new spot to get some fresh Cajun seafood, look no further!” 4647 Convoy St Suite B(858) 987-0333 Photo: Yelp Debut Dinner Menu: The Cork & Craft Newly appointed executive chef Scott Cannon recently launched his debut dinner menu at Rancho Bernardo food and beverage trifecta The Cork & Craft . Expect bold, beautifully presented dishes like Wagyu beef tartare with Fresno chilies, and a Colorado lamb duo of grilled lamb chops and lamb shoulder. There’s a roasted game hen, and searedscallops with Okinawa sweet potato purée. Pastry chef Brenda Gonzalez has created a variety of sweets for the dessert menu too, including a decadent yet delicate chocolate mousse crêpe cake with Mostra coffee ice cream and duck fat caramel. 16990 Via Tazon (858) 618-2463 Courtesy Photo New Winter Menu: Union Kitchen & Tap Encinitas Encinitas’ popular neighborhood tavern just rolled out its new winter dinner menu, highlights of which include hearty dishes such as wild boar ragu, acorn squash risotto, and duck confit with foie gras butter. Look out for more local spirits and housemade syrups on the cocktail menu too, a current standout is the San Pedro Star made with Malahat Cabernet Rum, Pedro Ximenez dessert sherry, Anguish & Regret liqueur ($14). During Friday happy hour (3 p.m. - 6 p.m.) enjoy $2 off craft cocktails, $5 local craft draft beers, $6 select wines and assorted $10 flatbreads. Weekend specials include $8 Manmosas, Bloody and Mexican Marys, plus $24.95 for any brunch entrée plus bottomless mimosas. 1108 S Coast Hwy 101 (760) 230-2337 Courtesy Photo New Chef & Menu Additions: Royal Stone Bistro Under the radar neighborhood gem Royal Stone recently brought on executive chef Aaron O’Mara to helm the kitchen at this Bankers Hill bistro. O’Mara, who has lived and worked in culinary hotspots including Chicago, San Francisco and New Orleans, was once a featured chef for the Food and Wine Gastronomy Society’s annual Chaine des Rotisseurs dinner. His latest additions to the seasonally driven menu include yummy bacon mousse on brioche toast, cremini mushroom gnocchi, and pecan-crusted chicken with mushroom cream sauce and wild rice. 3401 1st Ave (619) 738-8550 Courtesy Photo JANUARY 6, 2017 New in North County: Pressed Juicery Racking up column inches in glossies from Angeleno to Vogue, tucked inside The Forum shopping center you’ll find the newest SD location of modish juice bar, Pressed Juicery. Here, health-conscious types can snap up cold-pressed juices, signature beverages, cold-pressed coffee and specialty waters in addition to 2 oz. functional shots and a curated selection of grab-and-go snacks. The new Carlsbad location also features Freeze , Pressed Juicery’s vegan, dairy-free and gluten-free frozen soft serve treat, which comes in chocolate, vanilla, greens and fruit flavors with healthy toppings like almond butter and cacao drizzle. 1911 Calle Barcelona (760) 652-5297 Courtesy Photo New Brunch Bites: Galaxy Taco New-wave modern Mexican mecca, Galaxy , just debuted new items on its Sunday Brunch menu. There’s a tasty pazole verde with pork, blue and white corn hominy, red cabbage, radish and avocado ($13) or $14 with a poached egg. Next up, pork huarache (or pulled pork flatbread for the uninitiated) withfried eggs, roasted tomatillo salsa, lime crema, cotija, radish, lettuce and cilantro ($14). If you’re hankering for something sweet try the wafflewith fresh cream, banana, lemon zest and Mexican chocolate dust ($12). Starting this Sunday, look out for bottomless Mimosa and Michelada offerings. 2259 Avenida De La Playa (858) 228-5655 Photo: Lyudmila Zotova Steamed Buns, Onigiri & More : Bao Beach Hotly anticipated new Patio Group concept Bao Beach opened just last month across from Saska’s on Mission Boulevard. Here you can feast on delicious, fluffy steamed buns (dubbed ‘Asian tacos’) filled with everything from Japanese fried chicken and Korean marinated beef to crispy fried shrimp. There’s on-the-go onigri too packed with spam, tuna and carnitas, while poke lovers will be pleased to know there are bowls of their favorite fish salad, including spicy and yuzu tuna versions. Don’t miss the bulgogi street fries topped with spicy sriracha ketchup for the ultimate “beach food” fix. 3735 Mission Blvd (858) 381-0033Photo: Facebook New Year, New Menu: Stuffed! In celebration of lobster season Stuffed! will be serving up a decadent Surf + Turf burger - filled with butter-poached lobster tail, pickled red onion, arugula and tartar sauce - throughout January only. And, in honor of the New Year, all burgers and sandwiches are now served with a choice of tater tots, fries or onion straws. Mark Your Calendars: Stuffed! is collaborating with Venissimo and Green Flash Brewing on a four-course paired tasting dinner at Liberty Public Market on Monday, January 23. Tickets are available online . 2820 Historic Decatur Road (760) 607-2123 Photo: Lyudmila Zotova New in North County: Oscars Mexican Seafood After expanding into East Village last spring, longstanding local taco favorite, Oscar’s just opened a brand spanking new location in North County - you’ll find it nestled inside the Encinitas Village Shopping Center near the Trader Joes. The group’s fifth restaurant concept will feature a familiar menu of ceviche and seafood-stuffed tacos, tortas, burritos and the like, however this particular location will not be serving wine or beer. 115 N El Camino Real (858) 488-6392 DECEMBER 16, 2016 New Brick & Mortar: The Brazilian Guys You can now find Farmers market favorites, The Brazilian Guys , in Mission Hills. While they’re regulars in Oceanside, Vista and Hillcrest each week, at Ricardo and Camilo ’s newly opened coffee shop staples like acai, cassava pie, tapioca crepes, and empanadas also await. Try the delicious Brazilian cheese bread "Pao de Queijo" basket with coffee or one of their caramelized sweet potato pies stuffed with shredded chicken, fresh avocados and cheddar cheese. Although not currently open on the weekend you can catch them until 2 p.m. on Friday. 3085 Reynard Way (619) 735-1655 Photo: Facebook Refreshed Menu: Garage Kitchen + Bar Since returning from a post at the Avalon Palm Springs, former Kitchen 4140 chef/owner Kurt Metzger has been consulting for local restaurants and hotels. His most recent influence can be seen on the just-released new menu at the Gaslamp’s Garage Kitchen + Bar . Collaborating with executive chef Brent Hersant , Metzger has revamped much of the food offerings, including the addition of elevated entrees that range from duck confit with ancient grain risotto to Valencia orange-glazed Mary’s Chicken and short rib bourgignon. The restaurant is currently offering a dinner and a show deal; every purchase of an entree gets you a free admission pass to its lively next door piano bar, The Shout! House. As for Metzger’s next gig, the chef is working on a regular pop-up dinner series that he’ll host in his own backyard. 655 4th Avenue (619) 231-6700 Photo: Courtesy image. Viking Inspired: Twisted Horn Mead & Cider Say hello to Twisted Horn, Vista’s new purveyor of fine meads and ciders. The Viking-inspired tasting room just soft-opened and early reports are favorable. In addition to three ciders there are five iterations of the historic beverage: Raven’s Claw (fresh boysenberries), Freyja’s Folly (orange blossom honey), Old Toby (star thistle), Wizen Elder (elderflower, mountain sage honey), and limited edition Mazer Reserve with strawberry and kiwi. Before its New Year grand opening (date and time still TBD), “Pillaging hours” at Twisted Horn run from 1 – 8 p.m. on Saturday, December 17 and 1 – 6 p.m. on Sunday, December 18 and Sunday, December. 1042 Mirada Court Photo: Instagram Tribal Owned Brewery: SR76 Beerworks San Diego brewer, Brian Scott (Firehouse, Mission, Karl Strauss) is the Brewmaster behind a new beer concept SR76 at Harrah’s Resort Southern California.
